subject: Gardening
title: Seeds That Launched Civilizations
description: A quick, practical guide to Seeds That Launched Civilizations.

hook.text: Wheat, rice, and corn. Three seeds created three separate civilizationsâ€”Mesopotamia, Asia, and Mesoamerica.

buildup.text: Agriculture started when humans began saving and replanting seeds. The Fertile Crescent, ~10,000 BC, was first.

discovery.text: Selecting bigger seeds each year gradually changed wild grasses into wheat. Unconscious breeding created our food crops.

twist.text: Agriculture didn't improve life initially. Farmers were shorter, sicker, and worked harder than hunter-gatherers.

climax.text: Seeds enabled civilizationâ€”cities, writing, armiesâ€”but at the cost of nutrition, equality, and freedom for millennia.

punchline.text: Seeds gave us civilization. They also gave us inequality.

quiz.question: What unexpected consequence did early agriculture have on human health?
options: Farmers immediately became taller and healthier than hunter-gatherers
Early farmers were shorter, sicker, and worked harder than hunter-gatherers
Agriculture had no measurable effect on human health or stature
